repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
fix for https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2159
(I started it earlier and had to finish it)

Potentially I went to wrong way, ready to comments.

comment_data.body: This looks like it breaks the general interface for `to_py_call_code`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2592,6 +2592,46 @@ def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_type=None):
             return self.base_type.find_cpp_operation_type(operator, operand_type)
         return None
 
+class CPtrToArraySliceType(CPtrType):
+    def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.to_py_function is not None:
+            return True
+        if not self.base_type.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+            return False
+
+        safe_typename = self.base_type.specialization_name()
+
+        to_py_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_py_%s" % safe_typename
+        to_tuple_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_tuple_%s" % safe_typename
+
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        context = {
+            'cname': to_py_function,
+            'to_tuple_cname': to_tuple_function,
+            'base_type': self.base_type,
+        }
+        env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "carray_slice.to_py", "CConvert.pyx",
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
+            context=context, compiler_directives=dict(env.global_scope().directives)))
+        self.to_tuple_function = to_tuple_function
+        self.to_py_function = to_py_function
+        return True
+
+    def to_py_call_code(self, source_code, start_code, stop_code, result_code, result_type, to_py_function=None):

comment_data.body:
Can you ever end up with `arg` as something that isn't a `SliceIndexNode`? For example:

    a = some_array[1:10]
    return a

Could `a` pick up the type from the indexing operation, but the coercion would happen to a `NameNode`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13192,6 +13200,16 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
 
     def generate_result_code(self, code):
         code.putln('%s; %s' % (
+            self.arg.type.to_py_call_code(

comment_data.body: Both functions seem symmetric, so they should use similar names as well.

+        to_tuple_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_tuple_%s" % safe_typename
+
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        context = {
+            'cname': to_py_function,
+            'to_tuple_cname': to_tuple_function,

comment_data.body: Yes. It seems to me that going through an implementation tree node would be better than going through the type system for this. A sliced array isn't really a type by itself.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2592,6 +2592,46 @@ def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_type=None):
             return self.base_type.find_cpp_operation_type(operator, operand_type)
         return None
 
+class CPtrToArraySliceType(CPtrType):
+    def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.to_py_function is not None:
+            return True
+        if not self.base_type.create_to_py_utility_code(env):

+        to_py_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_py_%s" % safe_typename

+        context = {
+            'cname': to_py_function,
+            'to_tuple_cname': to_tuple_function,
+            'base_type': self.base_type,

comment_data.body: Makes total sense to have these two versions, but the tuple case doesn't seem to be exercised in the tests.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2592,6 +2592,46 @@ def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_type=None):
             return self.base_type.find_cpp_operation_type(operator, operand_type)
         return None
 
+class CPtrToArraySliceType(CPtrType):
+    def create_to_py_utility_code(self, env):
+        if self.to_py_function is not None:
+            return True
+        if not self.base_type.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+            return False
+
+        safe_typename = self.base_type.specialization_name()
+
+        to_py_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_py_%s" % safe_typename
+        to_tuple_function = "__Pyx_carray_slice_to_tuple_%s" % safe_typename
+
+        from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+        context = {
+            'cname': to_py_function,
+            'to_tuple_cname': to_tuple_function,
+            'base_type': self.base_type,
+        }
+        env.use_utility_code(CythonUtilityCode.load(
+            "carray_slice.to_py", "CConvert.pyx",
+            outer_module_scope=env.global_scope(),  # need access to types declared in module
+            context=context, compiler_directives=dict(env.global_scope().directives)))
+        self.to_tuple_function = to_tuple_function
+        self.to_py_function = to_py_function
+        return True
+
+    def to_py_call_code(self, source_code, start_code, stop_code, result_code, result_type, to_py_function=None):
+        func = self.to_py_function if to_py_function is None else to_py_function
+
+        target_is_tuple = result_type.is_builtin_type and result_type.name == 'tuple'

comment_data.body: I little bit forgot what is there, I know that I did it by potentially wrong way, comments will help to understand where are errors

commit.message: Coercion for sliced C array has been added
Test for coercion of sliced C array

title: [wip]Coercing sliced array to Python  object
